awd_titl_txt: SuperDARN in Ireland: A Mid-Latitude Geospace Facility to Study Electrodynamic Coupling in the European and Scandinavian Sectors
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project involves the construction and calibration of a pair of Super-DARN radars at a single site in central Ireland. The two SuperDARN radars, with a combined field-of-view exceeding ±75 in azimuth centered on the magnetic meridian, will be capable of making measurements of the ionospheric electric field over a region that includes eastern North America, Greenland, Iceland, Scandinavia and western Russia. Measurements in this sector, currently limited to the region north of 65 latitude, will extend the capabilities of the SuperDarn network to provide near real-time maps of the convection electric field during an expanded range of geomagnetic activity levels and increase the local time (LT) coverage to more than 12 hours. Existing radars at similar latitudes have demonstrated the importance of measurements from radars located at mid-latitudes during quiet to more active geomagnetic conditions and in particular, the ability of these radars to make detailed measurements of the sub-auroral polarization stream (SAPS) on rapid timescales (<1 min) over an extended range (>8 hours LT).  The installation of the two SuperDarn radars in Ireland would make possible investigations of longitudinal differences associated with the South Atlantic Anomaly in SAPS and electric field structuring as well as conjugate studies with southern hemisphere radars. In line with the geospace community review panel recommendations, distributed networks of ground-based instruments are quite valuable in resolving space-time ambiguities associated with sparse measurements of the space environment and making progress toward the science goals of the Solar Wind-Magnetosphere Interactions. The Ireland radars will significantly increase measurements of the electric field at mid-latitudes enabling SuperDARN to provide real-time observations of space weather disturbances in the ionosphere extending from Asia, across North America and into Northern Europe.  This should result in significant progress toward the larger goal of providing the capability to predict the effects of solar variability on the environment and on society.

An important aspect of the proposed project is the calibration of SuperDARN elevation angle measurements which can be used to improve the geolocation of backscattered signals, to discriminate between propagation modes and to estimate the index of refraction at the scattering location - this is now normally done by modeling using ray tracing software, and such models might be in error at times.
The project includes a small augmentation that will enable one of the interferometer arrays to be configurable and allow for testing of the sensitivity and accuracy of SuperDARN interferometers. Ireland is ideally situated for interferometer testing with two Scandinavian ionospheric heating facilities providing a calibration source within the field-of-view of the augmented radar. The project would very efficiently reuse most of a ready-to-go radar system that for various logistical and political reasons never got installed in the Azores. This is a highly targeted re-purposed application that minimizes substantially the installation budget.

por.por_cntn:
Two scientific, high-frequency radars were constructed at a location near Pykkvibaer, Iceland. These radars are part of the international collaboration known as the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) - a collection of similar radar systems that measure the motion of the ionized atmosphere in the region known as the ionosphere. Measurements from these radars are used to infer a picture of the plasma (ionized gas) flow in the polar regions of the Earth, which allows scientists to study the coupling that occurs between the solar wind (outermost extent of the Sun's atmosphere) and Earth's magnetosphere-iononosphere-thermosphere system (the magnetic and plasma environment surrounding the Earth).

The radars were constructed at a location in Iceland after delays were encountered in identifying a suitable site in Ireland. The radars were eventually built at a site in Iceland where a SuperDARN radar operated between 1995 and 2018. In 2018 this radar, and a companion radar located ~30km away, were decomissioned, leaving a large measurement gap in the region extending from northern Canada to northern Scandinavia. On January 24, 2023 at ~2000 UT, the Iceland radars, referred to as ICW and ICE (for Iceland West and East), made their first measurements (first-light). The radars have been operating nearly continuously since they first began operating, providing critical measurements of plasma motion over this important region in the northern hemisphere.

Construction of the radars began late in the summer of 2020 when international travel was prohibited by the US State Department due to the COVID pandemic. A local crew carefully surveyed and installed 64 concrete piers at precise locations over a ~20 acre area at the site. Equipment, purchased on a separate grant, was packaged and successfully shipped from the US to Iceland in three 40' shipping containers. However, delays due to the international shipping crisis prevented further construction progress in 2021.

Starting in May, 2022 the PI traveled to the site in Iceland eight times for periods of 7-10 days, working with accompanying students, scientists and local contractors to assemble, install, align and tension 64 antenna support poles; fabricate, install and tension four wire reflectors; attach 80 antenna halves; measure, install and phase-match 40 750' direct burial coaxial cables; and assemble and integrate radar transmit and receive electronics and computers. First-light was achieved around 2000 UT on January 24, 2023. Several additional trips were required to provide remote access to the site and improve climate control in the equipment shelter.

Since first-light, measurements from the Iceland SuperDARN radars have contributed to the overall specification of the large-scale motion of plasma in the ionosphere over Earth's northern polar region. The impact of these radars was immediate, with measurements revealing details of the plasma flow over a large region extending north of Iceland. Regular observations of regional plasma motion are being used in numerous scientific studies of various plasma phenomena that occur in the ionosphere, revealing a better understanding of the ionosphere and coupling processes to the thermosphere and magnetosphere regions.

The project was a success. Two new SuperDARN radars were built and are providing continuous measurements of plasma flow over a region north of Iceland in the Scandinavian sector. Numerous training opportunities were provided to students and early career scientists, who assisted in the construction of an NSF-funded scientific facility. Engagement with the local community and the University of Iceland, was critical to the project success and in the continued operation of the radars.
